lead_paragraph: FREILICH--Dr. Gerald. Emeritus professor of mathematics at Queens College of SUNY who specialized in geometric measure theory, passed away on December 27th, 2015 at age 88. Professor Freilich was the author of several books and many research articles and reviews in academic journals. He was a former governor of the Mathematical Association of America as well as Chairman of the New York Metropolitan Section and served on the national panel of the Committee on the Undergraduate Program of Mathematics. Born in Brooklyn, he received a bachelor's degree, Summa Cum Laude, from City College in 1946 and a Doctorate in Mathematics from Brown University in 1949. He taught at Brown University and then at City College of New York, advancing to full professor and Chairman of the Mathematics Department in 1966. During those years, he was an original member of the organizing Committee of the SUNY Doctoral Program and single-handedly established the SUNY graduate Mathematics Library. He also taught at Wesleyan University as a visiting professor. He joined the faculty of Queens College in 1971 and taught there until his retirement in 1995. Professor Freilich served in the US Navy in World War II. After the war, he was a Lieutenant J.G. in the Navy Reserves. He also did research for the National Ordinance Lab on helicopters and submarines. He was survived by Marion (nee Freudenberger) after 62 years of marriage. He is also survived by his brother Dr. Herbert Feilich and children Sandra Novetsky (Dr. Gary) and Dr. David Freilich (Erica) as well as eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren and many nephews and nieces. 1/3
